Dictionary of statespacer

Source: vignettes/dictionary.Rmd
dictionary.Rmd

This document provides extensive details about the object as returned by StateSpaceFit(). In order to do so, we start with introducing the form of the general linear Gaussian state space model, following the notation used by Durbin and Koopman (2012). Obtaining a grasp of the notation used will help to get the most out of the statespacer package!

The general linear Gaussian state space model

There are many ways to write down the form of the general linear Gaussian state space model. We use the form used by Durbin and Koopman (2012):

\[ \begin{aligned} y_t ~ &= ~ Z_t\alpha_t ~ + ~ \varepsilon_t, ~~~~~~~~~~ \varepsilon_t ~ \sim ~ N(0, ~ H_t), \\ \alpha_{t+1} ~ &= ~ T_t\alpha_t ~ + ~ R_t\eta_t, ~~~~~~ \eta_t ~ \sim ~ N(0, ~ Q_t), \end{aligned} \]

where \(y_t\) is the observation vector, a \(p ~ \times ~ 1\) vector of dependent variables at time \(t\). \(\alpha_t\) is the unobserved state vector, a \(m ~ \times ~ 1\) vector of state variables at time \(t\). \(\varepsilon_t\) and \(\eta_t\) are disturbance vectors of respectively the observation equation, and the state equation. The matrices \(Z_t\), \(H_t\), \(T_t\), \(R_t\), and \(Q_t\) are called the system matrices of the state space model. Different specifications of the system matrices, lead to different interpretations of the model.

The object as returned by StateSpaceFit

Having obtained a better understanding of the notation used, it is easier to find our way in the object as returned by StateSpaceFit(). Let’s say we store the object of StateSpaceFit in a variable called fit, that is, fit <- StateSpaceFit(...). fit is then a list, containing many items, including other lists. This section describes the items that are included in fit one by one.

function_call

References

Durbin, James, and Siem Jan Koopman. 2012. Time Series Analysis by State Space Methods. Oxford university press.
